body.p: The IASB has included application guidance to help determine the circumstances in which substitution rights are substantive. This guidance focuses on whether the supplier has the practical ability to substitute the asset and would benefit economically from doing so. The IASB’s intention in including this guidance is to differentiate between:

li.p: substitution rights that result in there being no identified asset because the supplier, rather than the customer, controls the use of an asset; and
substitution rights that do not change the substance or character of the contract because it is not likely, or practically or economically feasible, for the supplier to exercise those rights.

body.p: If a substitution clause is not substantive because it does not change the substance of the contract, then that substitution clause should not affect an entity’s assessment of whether a contract contains a lease. The IASB thinks that, in many cases, it will be clear that the supplier would not benefit from the exercise of a substitution right because of the costs associated with substituting an asset.
